From: "Dave Astels" <dave@...>
Sent: Sunday, October 13, 2002 8:46 AM


> On Sun, 2002-10-13 at 13:33, Levi Cook wrote:
> >
> > From: "Dave Astels" <dave@...>
> > Sent: Sunday, October 13, 2002 12:56 AM
> >
> > > > The "Type-Hierarchy" view in Eclipse (&WSAD) can also be very useful
to
> > > > get a quick idea of what relationships exist.
> > >
> > > But that only shows inheritance & implementation hierarchies, which
> > > should be fairly small anyway.  Very little information compared to a
> > > good class diagram.
> >
> > Agreed :)
> >
> > As it relates to JUnit; A view of my projects I find interesting is to
open
> > the type-heirarchy with TestCase at the top.
> >
> > Now that I think of it; it could jump from interesting to downright
useful
>
> For TestCases or TestSuites?

TestCases --> I'm still in a world of manually maintained suite methods...

> why not let them be collected automatically?

Project specific conventions; We're overloading JUnit to handle sub-system
testing too...

Our suite hierarchies; for better or worse; tend to look like this:
AllTests
    AllBatchTests-Suite
        AllBatchTests-InProgress-Suite
            AllDailyBatchTests-InProgress-Suite
            AllMonthlyBatchTests-InProgress-Suite
        AllBatchTests-Done-Suite
            AllDailyBatchTests-Done-Suite
            AllMonthlyBatchTests-Done-Suite

It helps at integration time in making sure things that are supposedly done
don't fail.

> if TestSuites: use New->TestSuite in Eclipse.  You can even select a
> TestSuite & use New->TestSuite to update it (gives a checkable list of
> accessible Tests to include in the generated suite method).

Stuck with WSAD 4.x for now..
